instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.C6990: What is C6990? Capacitor to ground on input to PP3V42_G3H power supply. PP3V42_G3H power supply turns 18.5v from charger or 8.5v-12.5v PPBUS_G3H from the battery into PP3V42_G3H. This capacitor can short to ground and keep PP3V42_G3H from turning on which would keep the machine from having a light on the magsafe charger.
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
wasn't really liquid damage but had a bit of corrsion on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. took it off and cleaned it.

<CHIP>U6901</CHIP> pin 5 only has .5v
<TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> gets really hot as well.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: At least <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/35 should be replaced. Check <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22/51/52 and traces to them. Maybe before you do anything check resistance to GND on PP3V42, if under 15K then MCP is probably also dead.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: changed u700 <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/35.  still same issue.  all the resistors traces are good.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: What same issue, I doubt <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> is still getting hot. What is PPBUS and 3V42 voltages?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> isnt getting hot anymore, but still .52v on 3v42

where should i measure ppbus?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: 3V42 is the first thing you need. Is there a short on 3V42? Resistance to GND on 3V42?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
no short on 3v42

res to ground is when you put red lead on ground pin and com lead on 3v42 right?  that reading is 9.28k

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR> - .557v
no corrosion on <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> area. i can replace it though if you think i should.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
I had a feeling my multimeter was giving out (was giving me weird readings on an iphone 6 i was testing) I just went and bought a new fluke multimeter and read 3v42 and am getting 1.19v on pin 5 (<CHIP>U6901</CHIP>)
<CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR> - 2.65v
